Fiction

THE DA VINCI CODE, by Dan Brown. (Doubleday, $24.95; special illustrated edition, $35.) A murder at the Louvre leads to clues found in the work of Leonardo and to the discovery of a centuries-old secret society.
STATE OF FEAR, by Michael Crichton. (HarperCollins, $27.95.) Reverse eco-terrorists create natural disasters to convince the public that global warming is real.

THE FIVE PEOPLE YOU MEET IN HEAVEN, by Mitch Albom. (Hyperion, $19.95.) An old man who died while trying to rescue a little girl from danger discovers that all will be explained to him in the afterlife.
LIFE EXPECTANCY, by Dean Koontz. (Bantam, $27.) A pastry chef must struggle all his life against a family of evil madmen.
NIGHT FALL, by Nelson DeMille. (Warner, $26.95.) A husband and wife who work for an antiterrorism task force reopen the investigation into T.W.A. Flight 800.
BLACK WIND, by Clive Cussler and Dirk Cussler. (Putnam, $27.95.) Dirk Pitt and his children confront a villain who has acquired biotoxins from World War II.
A SALTY PIECE OF LAND, by Jimmy Buffett. (Little, Brown, $27.95.) A cowboy's life is changed when a 101-year-old woman hires him to be a lighthouse keeper.
LONDON BRIDGES, by James Patterson. (Little, Brown, $27.95.) The F.B.I. agent Alex Cross contends with two deadly enemies: the Wolf and the Weasel.
BY ORDER OF THE PRESIDENT, by W. E. B. Griffin. (Putnam, $26.95.) An Army officer tries to thwart a terrorist plot to crash a stolen 727 into the Liberty Bell.
HOT TARGET, by Suzanne Brockmann. (Ballantine, $19.95.) A movie producer receives death threats because of her latest film -- a World War II epic that depicts the homosexuality of a real-life hero.
I AM CHARLOTTE SIMMONS, by Tom Wolfe. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $28.95.) A smart, innocent freshman is amazed by what she finds at a prestigious university.
WHITEOUT, by Ken Follett. (Dutton, $26.95.) In the middle of a Christmas Eve blizzard in Scotland, a canister filled with a deadly virus goes missing.

THE PLOT AGAINST AMERICA, by Philip Roth. (Houghton Mifflin, $26.) The experiences of a Jewish family in Newark after Charles A. Lindbergh defeats Franklin D. Roosevelt in the 1940 presidential election.
JONATHAN STRANGE & MR. NORRELL, by Susanna Clarke. (Bloomsbury, $27.95.) A literary fantasy featuring two 19th-century English magicians.
METRO GIRL, by Janet Evanovich. (HarperCollins, $26.95.) A woman scours Florida and Cuba in search of her trouble-prone younger brother.
*THE CAT WHO WENT BANANAS, by Lilian Jackson Braun. (Putnam, $23.95.) Jim Qwilleran and his cats investigate the suspicious death of an actor.

List
Nonfiction
AMERICA (The BOOK), by Jon Stewart, Ben Karlin, David Javerbaum et al. (Warner, $24.95.) ''The Daily Show'' offers a lavishly illustrated parody of a civics textbook.
CHRONICLES: Volume One, by Bob Dylan. (Simon & Schuster, $24.) Recollections and observations from the singer-songwriter.
HIS EXCELLENCY, by Joseph J. Ellis. (Knopf, $26.95.) A biography of George Washington, by the author of ''Founding Brothers.''
WHEN WILL JESUS BRING THE PORK CHOPS? by George Carlin. (Hyperion, $23.95.) Another volume of observations and opinions from the stand-up comedian.
EATS, SHOOTS & LEAVES, by Lynne Truss. (Gotham, $17.50.) An Englishwoman expounds on the use and misuse of punctuation marks.
COLLAPSE, by Jared Diamond. (Viking, $29.95.) A historical investigation, by the author of ''Guns, Germs, and Steel,'' into why some societies succeed while others fail.
FAITHFUL, by Stewart O'Nan and Stephen King. (Scribner, $26.) Two novelists -- and die-hard Boston Red Sox fans -- chronicle the 2004 championship season, from spring training to the World Series.
WILL IN THE WORLD, by Stephen Greenblatt. (Norton, $26.95.) A Harvard humanities professor sets out to explain how Shakespeare became the greatest of all playwrights.
HOW TO TALK TO A LIBERAL (IF YOU MUST), by Ann Coulter. (Crown Forum, $26.95.) A collection of the columnist's writings about what's wrong with liberals.
WHAT'S THE MATTER WITH KANSAS? by Thomas Frank. (Metropolitan/Holt, $24.) An examination of what the author calls the Great Backlash, in which conservatives ''won the heart of America.''
MARV LEVY: Where Else Would You Rather Be? by Marv Levy. (Sports Publishing L.L.C., $24.95.) The autobiography of the former head coach of the Buffalo Bills.
THE LAST SEASON, by Phil Jackson with Michael Arkush. (Penguin Press, $24.95.) The former coach of the Los Angeles Lakers recalls his final year with Shaquille O'Neal and Kobe Bryant.
MY LIFE, by Bill Clinton. (Knopf, $35.) From Hope, Ark., to the White House: the autobiography of the 42nd president.
FAVRE, by Brett Favre and Bonita Favre with Chris Havel. (N.F.L. Publishing/RuggedLand, $29.95.) A profusely illustrated book about the Green Bay Packers' quarterback.
IN FOCUS. (National Geographic Society, $30.) A collection of more than 250 of National Geographic magazine's ''greatest portraits.''

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended Jan. 1, at almost 4,000 bookstores plus wholesalers serving 50,000 other retailers, statistically weighted to represent all such outlets nationwide. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (+) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available at The New York Times on the Web: nytimes.com/books.
Editors' Choice Other recent books of particular interest
THE WORLD OF CHRISTOPHER MARLOWE, by David Riggs. (John Macrae/Holt, $30.) The life and times of a spy, brawler and great poet.
THE DICTATORS: Hitler's Germany and Stalin's Russia, by Richard Overy. (Norton, $35.) A historian seeks the essence of totalitarianism.
ARMAGEDDON: The Battle for Germany, 1944-1945, by Max Hastings. (Knopf, $30.) Though obviously beaten, the Germans wouldn't give up; a veteran journalist pursues the paradox.

THOUGH THE HEAVENS MAY FALL: The Landmark Trial That Led to the End of Human Slavery, by Steven M. Wise. (Da Capo, $25.) The 1772 London case that found slavery so offensive the laws of England would not enforce it.

BURY THE CHAINS: Prophets and Rebels in the Fight to Free an Empire's Slaves, by Adam Hochschild. (Houghton Mifflin, $26.95.) How the struggle availed, especially when black Haitian armies beat white French and British ones.
THE INTIMATE WORLD OF ABRAHAM LINCOLN, by C. A. Tripp. (Free Press, $27.) The case that Lincoln was gay, plausibly presented.
102 MINUTES: The Untold Story of the Fight to Survive Inside the Twin Towers, by Jim Dwyer and Kevin Flynn. (Times Books/Holt, $26.) A skilled reconstruction by writers at The Times.
SIGHTSEEING: Stories, by Rattawut Lapcharoensap. (Grove, $19.95.) Articulate fiction about coming of age in Southeast Asia.
CITIZEN: Poems, by Andrew Feld. (Perennial/ HarperCollins, paper, $12.95.) Disciplined, intellectual work in natural syntax, and enough fantasy to allow a poem from Bebe Rebozo's point of view.
THE MAN IN THE FLYING LAWN CHAIR: And Other Excursions and Observations, by George Plimpton. (Random House, $24.95.) A posthumous volume on eccentrics, dreamers and the rest of us.

THE BOYS OF WINTER: The Untold Story of a Coach, a Dream, and the 1980 U.S. Olympic Hockey Team, by Wayne Coffey. (Crown, $23.95.) Portraits of a brilliant, intense coach and the men he led to victory over the Russians.
The full reviews of these and other recent books are on the Web: nytimes.com/books
